title: A Teaching Journey in Statistics
text:
Something about me…


I am an Assistant Professor of Teaching.
My graduate teaching is focused on the Master of Data Science (MDS), specifically in Statistics.
My undergraduate teaching has been focused on scientific communication.
I am somehow still active in my core PhD research area: Spatio-temporal data modelling (such as Gaussian stochastic processes).

1. Statistical Food for Thought

We can view Statistics as an auxiliary science that helps us to learn helpful population/system insights through sampled data.

2. Overview of the Teaching Journey


Teaching assistant (2014-2020):


STAT 200: Elementary Statistics for Applications in Science.
STAT 251: Elementary Statistics for Engineering.
STAT 305: Introduction to Statistical Inference.
STAT 404: Design and Analysis of Experiments.


Graduate Statistical Consultant (2017-2020) at the Statistical Opportunity for Students (SOS) program and Short Term Consulting Service (STCS).

title: A Teaching Journey in Statistics
text:
3. Teaching Philosophy



I believe every person’s teaching philosophy begins with their respective learning experiences across their academic life. Therefore, I define teaching as a meticulous and flexible process that must be adapted to the students’ background expertise level.





This flexibility can be achieved in conjunction with diverse team building and technological tools. Moreover, I always strive to incorporate robust conceptual frameworks at any statistical course level.

title: A Teaching Journey in Statistics
text:
4. A Practical Teaching Case: DSCI 562

There are eight lectures, four labs, and two exams.
How can we cover generalized linear models (GLMs), mixed-effects, local, survival, and quantile regression, and techniques for dealing with missing data across eight lectures in four weeks?

title: A Teaching Journey in Statistics
text:
5. Challenges Ahead



Open Educational Resources (OERs) are still heavily needed in Machine Learning, Statistics, and Data Science.
We are currently working on that! The Regression Cookbook is our first approach!
Another project is on the way: The Hypothesis Testing Mini Cookbook.
Keep exploring new ways to deliver audiovisual teaching materials such as YouTube using UBC Studios.
Expand our current statistical curriculum via external collaborations.
